text: In my investigations into the historicity of Jesus Christ this is one of the books I read, and unfortunately found it was one of the weakest. The subtitle is "A Journalist's Personal Investigation of the Evidence for Jesus", but all Lee does is interview believers who give him a biased one sided view and then just accepts it without checking it out for himself!  Hardly an "investigation". If it was a proper investigation he would have not just blindly accepted what they said but checked it out for himself, interviewing people with a counter point to have a balanced opinion.  The only use this book has is it raises points which the readers CAN then investigate themselves. This is what I did and cam e to a conclusion the opposite of that to the author's.

text: There seem to be a lot of Christians in this comment section (hardly a surprise), so hopefully one of you can explain something to me. The problem of Hell (why would an all-loving god send people to Hell) is something that comes up quite a bit when discussing Christianity, and most Christians give basically the same response: God is just, so he cannot allow sinners into Heaven without a redeemer. My question is, how does this "redeemer" idea make any sense? Imagine, for a moment, that there is a convicted serial killer facing a judge in a courtroom... The serial killer tells the judge, "Hey, you seem like a nice guy, you should just let me go without any punishment." The judge replies, "I can't just let you go. You're a serial killer. It would be unjust to let you free without punishment." The serial killer then says, "Well, I have a friend here. This friend of mine has never done anything wrong in his entire life, and he's agreed to take my punishment on my behalf if you let me go." The judge replies, "Oh, in that case, you're free to go. Allowing a killer like yourself to go without punishment would be unjust, but punishing an innocent person and *then* letting the killer go without punishment is perfectly just."  In that scenario, the judge seems like he's out of his mind. Surely punishing an innocent person and then letting a killer go free would be *less* just than simply letting the killer go free. So why is it that, to Christians, the story of Jesus doesn't sound equally ridiculous? How can the death of an innocent redeem the wrongdoings of the guilty in the eyes of a god that is supposedly just?

text: I think the book raised some interesting questions/points about Yeshua/Jesus, but "PURE" FLIX and "from the creators of 'God's not Dead'" are about all one needs to read to know that this movie is created to serve its own subculture.  Evangelical Christianity is predominantly one of the most paradoxically named cultures in the west. Those who claim to be one seem to (generally) have some of the worst understanding of the life and message of Jesus, let alone humanity at large.  *And I truly only intend these comments as observations, not criticisms.  Jesus was the friend to all of humanity. He had no "side" other than life, love, self sacrifice, hope, forgiveness, and a true pursuit of justice and religion.  The fact that any Christian in the west feels like he or she can't stand comfortably beside a person of any other belief system—including the "oh so dangerous" atheism—shows that the message of Christ has become diluted and lost within the practice of politics and false religion.  And furthermore, everyone's human here. No one absolutely knows anything nor absolutely doesn't question anything. And that needs to be ok.  Peace all. Just my little rant / 2 cents. Let's all be kind to each other and never stop exploring and discovering what is true and meaningful.
author: yrlk

text: Lee Strobel's 1998 best-selling book The Case for Christ became dated last year with the groundbreaking discovery that had been right there in plain sight the last 2,000 years...the Roman garrison's immobilization in the Temple as Jesus wrestles control of the Temple from the Roman soldiers... https://sites.google.com/site/deanjackson60/the-deft-political-maneuverings-of-jesus-and-jewish-officials-under-a-precarious-roman-shadow The Temple complex was controlled by the Roman legion housed in the adjacent Antonia Fortress... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonia_Fortress  During festival periods, such as Passover Week, Roman soldiers would be placed in the Temple's cloisters... http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-E2U77rRIqGI/UTCiGiTJnBI/AAAAAAAAGDA/tZO0Wli62A8/s1600/Acts+21+-+Paul+temple+Riot.jpg ... so that they could react quickly for any sign of trouble brewing in the courtyards, but in the case of Jesus who twice cleared the Temple's courtyards, the Roman garrison could do nothing! This is positive empirical proof that Jesus is who He claimed to be, thanks to the unbiased Romans who were immobilized. This discovery fulfills Jesus' instruction that there were certain items kept out of the Gospels, but that those items could be seen clearly by those with eyes to see... "For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed, and nothing concealed that will not be known or brought out into the open.  Therefore consider carefully how you listen. Whoever has will be given more; whoever does not have, even what they think they have will be taken from them." https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%208:17-18 A movie needs to be produced detailing the Roman immobilization as Jesus TWICE clears the Temple.

text: I read this book back in my Campus Crusade days and was quite convinced by the argument at the time. Lee Stobel is a kind and seemingly well meaning guy. A few years of watching debates later and actually reading the reasoned arguments against supernatural divine revelation and I'm an agnostic atheist. I re-read The Case for Christ to see if the arguments held up. They didn't. Strobel's methodology is wildly flawed, the same case works for Mormonism.

text: I have read a lot of comments and discussions about how one can belief in such a fairy tale.  I tell you until you have a personal relationship with Jesus your Lord and Savior, you would not ever understand.  How do we know he is real?  Because I talk to him daily.  How do I know he is real?  because of the answered and the unanswered prayers.  How do I know God loves me?  Because of the blessings and the struggles that make me trust in him.  My faith is not built on an imaginary anything.  It is built on the proof of prayer and conversations that I have with my savior daily. Call me a nut, call me crazy, call me all the things you can think of.  But, all I can do is pray that one day you  the very one calling me names can feel this happiness that only Jesus can supply.
